		<div class="wrap clearfix page-sub-title recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="column12">

		<div class="row content recessed-content">
			<div class="wrap clearfix">
				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
						<h1>Information for Prospective Graduate Students</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->
<img src="images/faculty.jpg" width="225" height="290" style="float:right;" />
    <p>This is an informal supplement to the detailed information about the structure of courses provided by the Faculty in the <a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk"><strong>Graduate Prospectus</strong></a>. It attempts to describe in general terms what the Cambridge English Faculty expects of its graduate students and what our graduate students can reasonably expect from us. </p>
    
    <ul>
      <li><a href="becoming-a-graduate.htm#1"><strong>Becoming a Graduate Student</strong></a></li>
      <li><a href="life-as-a-graduate.htm"><strong>Life as a Graduate Student</strong></a></li>
    </ul>



    <p>We also have specific information about our 1 year MPhil courses,    
    <ul class="style2">
    <li><a href="MPhil_Info_AmLit.htm">American Literature</a></li>
    
    <li><a href="http://www.asnc.cam.ac.uk/admissions/graduate/index.htm#mphil">Anglo-Saxon, Norse, and Celtic</a></li>
    <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_Criticism_Culture.htm">English Studies: Criticism and Culture</a></li>
    <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_1700.htm">English Studies: 18th Century and Romantic Studies </a></li>
    <li><a href="MPhil_Info_Modern.htm">English Studies: Modern and Contemporary Literature </a></li>
    <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_MedRen.htm">Medieval and Renaissance Literature </a></li>
    
    </ul>
    <p>Please note that although prospective graduate students may   wish to look at the list of faculty members' research interests before   they decide to apply here, supervisors aren't appointed until   <strong>after</strong> the candidate has been accepted and can't appoint themselves to   supervise a project in advance.<br />
</p>
<p>To access the online application form please go to the <a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk"> Graduate Admissions website</a>. Information about funding and making an application are located in the navigation menu.</p>
<strong>*The final deadline for applications is 4 January 2018*</strong>
<p> If you have any  other queries about the admissions process please contact:</p>
    <p>          <em><a href="mailto:af285@cam.ac.uk">Anna  Fox</a></em><br />
      <em>Senior  Secretary</em><br />
      <em>9 West    Road<br />
      Cambridge CB3    9DP<br />
      United Kingdom</em></p>
    <p><em>Tel. 01223  335076 </em></p>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

				    <div class="heading-container">
					<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="RelatedLinksTitle" -->							
                       <h2> Related Links</h2>
					   <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
				    </div><!-- end heading container -->
					  
                      <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="RelatedLinks" -->
                      <br /><h2>Applying</h2>
<ul class='unstyled-list related-links'>
  <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/index.htm">Graduate Admissions</a></li>
  <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/Application_Info.htm">How to apply</a></li>
  <li> <a href="/admissions/graduate/Funding_Home.htm">Funding for home and EU students</a></li>
  <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/Funding_OS.htm">Funding for overseas students</a></li>
  <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/research_prop.htm">Research proposals</a></li>
  <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/becoming-a-graduate.htm#1">Becoming a Graduate Student</a></li>
  <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/life-as-a-graduate.htm#8">Life as a Graduate Student</a></li>
</ul>
<br /><h2>Courses</h2>
   <ul class='unstyled-list related-links'>
    <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_AmLit.htm">American Literature</a></li>
    <li><a href="http://www.asnc.cam.ac.uk/admissions/graduate/index.htm#mphil">Anglo-Saxon, Norse, and Celtic </a></li>
    <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_Criticism_Culture.htm">English Studies: Criticism and Culture</a></li>
    <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_1700.htm">English Studies: 18th Century and Romantic Studies</a></li>
   <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_Modern.htm">English Studies: Modern and Contemporary Literature</a></li>
     <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/MPhil_Info_MedRen.htm">Medieval and Renaissance Literature</a></li>
    <li><a href="/admissions/graduate/PhD.htm">PhD</a></li>
    <li><a href="PhD_Part-time.htm">Part-time PhD</a></li>

    <li><a href="http://www.ice.cam.ac.uk/course/mst-creative-writing">M.St. in Creative Writing</a> (run by the Institute of Continuing Education)</li>
   </ul>
					  <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	
					</div> <!-- end content container -->
					<div class="content-container"><!--Promo Container would go here --></div>
				</div> <!-- end column3 -->
			</div>	<!-- end wrap -->
		</div> <!-- end row -->

<style type="text/css">
#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}
</style>
<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>
<a href='#' id='w2b-StoTop' style='display:none;'>Scroll to start<br />of page.</a><!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

	</ul>
</li>
<li><a class="" href="http://www.english.cam.ac.uk/news/">News</a></li>
</ul>
		<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
    		<!-- Menu ends -->
			</div>
		</div>



		<div class="wrap clearfix page-sub-title recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="column12">
				<div class="content-container">
				<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="SectionTitle" -->
                	<p class="sub-title">Graduate Admissions</p>
				<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
   				</div>
			</div>
		</div>
	</div>


		<div class="row content recessed-content">
			<div class="wrap clearfix">
				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
						<h1>How to Apply</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->
<p>To start the application process you must first visit the <a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk/"> <strong>Graduate Admissions website</strong> </a> where you will be able to access the online application facility. </p>
<p>Application forms for entry in October 2018 will be available from 3 September 2017.</p>
<p>Once you have submitted your online application form you will be sent an email with details on how to  access  your Self-Service Account. </p>
<p>The final deadline for submitting applications for entry in October 2017 is 4 January 2018. </p>


<H2>Supporting Documents</H2></p>
<a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk/how-do-i-apply/supporting-documentation/academic-references">First Academic Reference</a>  
<p>Second Academic Reference  </p>
<p><a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk/how-do-i-apply/supporting-documentation/transcripts">Transcript</a>  </p>
<p><a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk/how-do-i-apply/supporting-documentation/evidence-competence-english">Evidence of Competence in English</a>  <br/>
  <em>If English is not your first language. This is not required if you are continuing from a Cambridge graduate course to the PhD </em></p>
<p><a href="research_prop.htm">Research Proposal</a>  <br/>
  <em>Enter a title and a short summary of your intended research on the online application form then submit a full research proposal as part of your supporting documents. This should be 500 words for an MPhil or 800 words for a PhD.</em></p>
<p>Sample of Academic Work  <br/>
  <em>This can be one long piece or several shorter essays ideally related to your proposed research.  </em></p>
<p><a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk/how-do-i-apply/supporting-documentation/personal-references">Personal Reference</a><br/> 
  <em>This is only required if you are applying for the Gates Cambridge Scholarship. </em></p>

  
    <h2>&nbsp;</h2><p><strong>Please note that if you are applying for the PhD you may be asked to interview in person, by telephone or by Skype. </strong></p>
<p align="justify">&nbsp;</p>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

						
				  </div> <!-- end content container -->
				</div> <!-- end column9 maincontent -->
				<div class="column3 secondary-content">
				  <div class="content-container">
				    <div class="heading-container">
					<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="RelatedLinksTitle" -->							
                       <h2>Related Links</h2>
					   <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
				    </div><!-- end heading container -->

#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}
</style>
<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>
<a href='#' id='w2b-StoTop' style='display:none;'>Scroll to start<br />of page.</a><!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
						<h1>Funding for Home/EU Graduate Students</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->

    <p><b>Arts & Humanities Research Council </b><strong> (AHRC) and Cambridge Trusts</strong></p>
    <p>If you wish to be considered for grants from the AHRC and the Cambridge Trusts you  must tick the appropriate boxes on the online application form.</p>
    <p>Applicants for the PhD who also wish to apply for the AHRC must submit with their supporting documents an additional <a href="http://www.ahrcdtp.csah.cam.ac.uk/information-prospective-students/apply">AHRC application form </a></p>
<p>http://www.ahrcdtp.csah.cam.ac.uk/information-prospective-students/apply</p>
    <p>If you have any queries please contact <a href="mailto:af285@cam.ac.uk">Anna Fox.</a></p>
<p>Further details of <a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk/finance/funding">Costs 
  and Sources of Funding</a> for graduate students are listed in the graduate 
  prospectus.</p>
    <p><strong>Judith E Wilson Studentship</strong> </p>
    <p>The Faculty of English is pleased to announce that the Judith E Wilson Studentship will be offered for funding towards a PhD in Drama<strong>*</strong> from October 2017. The studentship will cover fees and maintenance for a PhD at the University’s home/EU rate. It is tenable for one year and will be renewed for a further two subject to satisfactory progress.  All students who are offered a place in the relevant fields for the studentship and who indicate that they are seeking funding will be considered for the award. The award will be made on the basis of the quality of the applicant’s academic record, the research proposal, and any other indications of outstanding academic merit. </p>
    <p><strong>*</strong>The Judith E Wilson Fund may be applied …  for the purpose of furthering the study of literature, especially of literature relating to drama and poetry, with particular emphasis on contemporary practices</p>
    <p><strong>Faculty of English Centenary Studentship</strong> </p>
    <p>The Faculty of English is pleased to announce a Centenary Studentship will be offered to candidates for PhD study from October 2017 in any area of English Literature. The studentship will cover fees and/or maintenance for a PhD at the University’s home/EU rate. It is tenable for one year and will be renewed for a further two subject to satisfactory progress. All students who are offered a place to study a PhD in the Faculty of English and who indicate that they are seeking funding will be considered for the award. </p>
    <p><strong>Gould MPhil Studentship in English Literature</a></strong></p>
    <p>The Gould Studentship in English Literature is a one-year studentship for students who wish to undertake a Masters Course in English Literature at the University of Cambridge. </p>
    <p>Candidates who propose to study English Literature for a MPhil course within another Faculty are also eligible to apply.      </p>
    <p>Students from any university may apply for the Gould Studentship in English Literature. Eligible candidates must have applied for admission, or already received an offer of admission, to the University of Cambridge for a MPhil course.</p>
    <p> On completion of the MPhil course, the student will be eligible to apply for a Trinity Internal Graduate Studentship at Trinity College in order to study for  the PhD degree.</p>
    <p>The Studentship covers:      <br/>
    1.	Graduate Course Fees for a one year course, and      <br/>
 2.	Discretionary maintenance allowance      </p>
    <p>An award will be conditional upon the applicant being accepted by the University’s Graduate Admissions Office for a course in the University. </p>
    <p>The successful applicant(s) must become member(s) of Trinity College on taking up the Studentship.
      
      Completed <a href="https://www.trin.cam.ac.uk/postgraduate/graduate-funding-awards/trinity-graduate-student-funding-awards-how-to-apply/">application forms</a> and all supporting documents must be submitted through the online application system by 12:00 noon (GMT) on Friday 20 January 2017. </p>
    <p><!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

						
				  </div> <!-- end content container -->

#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}
</style>
<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>

				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
						<h1>Funding for Overseas Graduate Students</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->
<p>The Faculty is keen to admit outstanding students from all over the world.</p>

<p>There are a number of awards and grants available to overseas students 
through the University. Details of all the awards can be found in the Graduate 
Prospectus <a href="http://www.graduate.study.cam.ac.uk/finance/funding">here</a>. </p>
<p>The <a href="http://www.cambridgetrusts.org/">Cambridge Trusts</a> (which includes the <a href="http://www.gatesscholar.org/">Gates Cambridge Trust</a>) offer scholarships and part-cost bursaries to students from overseas and the European Union (excluding the United Kingdom) who have been accepted for admission to the University of Cambridge.</p>
<p>Some of the Colleges offer graduate awards and bursaries 
each year. Details of these awards can be found in the special November 
issue of the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/reporter/">University Reporter</a>.</p>
<p>Before you arrive you will have to satisfy the Graduate Admissions Office that you have sufficient funding for your proposed course. Many 
  overseas students obtain awards from their normal place of residence. Details 
  of present levels of fees can be found in the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/students/gradadmissions/prospec/studying/feecost/">Graduate 
    Prospectus</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Judith E Wilson Studentship</strong> </p>
    <p>The Faculty of English is pleased to announce that the Judith E Wilson Studentship will be offered for funding towards a PhD in Drama<strong>*</strong> from October 2017. The studentship will cover fees and maintenance for a PhD at the University’s home/EU rate. It is tenable for one year and will be renewed for a further two subject to satisfactory progress.  All students who are offered a place in the relevant fields for the studentship and who indicate that they are seeking funding will be considered for the award. The award will be made on the basis of the quality of the applicant’s academic record, the research proposal, and any other indications of outstanding academic merit. </p>
    <p><strong>*</strong>The Judith E Wilson Fund may be applied …  for the purpose of furthering the study of literature, especially of literature relating to drama and poetry, with particular emphasis on contemporary practices</p>
  <p><strong>Gould MPhil Studentship in English Literature</a></strong></p>
    <p>The Gould Studentship in English Literature is a one-year studentship for students who wish to undertake a Masters Course in English Literature at the University of Cambridge. </p>
    <p>Candidates who propose to study English Literature for a MPhil course within another Faculty are also eligible to apply.      </p>
    <p>Students from any university may apply for the Gould Studentship in English Literature. Eligible candidates must have applied for admission, or already received an offer of admission, to the University of Cambridge for a MPhil course.</p>
    <p> On completion of the MPhil course, the student will be eligible to apply for a Trinity Internal Graduate Studentship at Trinity College in order to study for  the PhD degree.</p>
    <p>The Studentship covers:      <br/>
    1.	Graduate Course Fees for a one year course, and      <br/>
 2.	Discretionary maintenance allowance      </p>
    <p>An award will be conditional upon the applicant being accepted by the University’s Graduate Admissions Office for a course in the University. </p>
    <p>The successful applicant(s) must become member(s) of Trinity College on taking up the Studentship.
      
      Completed <a href="https://www.trin.cam.ac.uk/postgraduate/graduate-funding-awards/trinity-graduate-student-funding-awards-how-to-apply/">application forms</a> and all supporting documents must be submitted through the online application system by 12:00 noon (GMT) on Friday 20 January 2017. </p>
<p> </p>
    <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

<style type="text/css">
#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}
</style>
<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>
<a href='#' id='w2b-StoTop' style='display:none;'>Scroll to start<br />of page.</a><!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

		<div class="wrap clearfix page-sub-title recessed-sub-title">
			<div class="column12">
				<div class="content-container">
				<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="SectionTitle" -->
                	<p class="sub-title">Graduate Admissions</p>

		<div class="row content recessed-content">
			<div class="wrap clearfix">
				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
						<h1>The M.Litt.</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->
<p>The M.Litt. is a research degree, examined, usually after two or more 
        years of research, by a dissertation of up to 60,000 words. The criteria 
        for obtaining the degree are that the dissertation represent a 'substantial 
        contribution to knowledge', but the criteria are adapted to take account 
        of the fact that the course lasts only two years.</p>
      <p><b>It should be noted that there is no formal taught element in this 
        course of study. It does not provide a suitable foundation course from 
        which to proceed to a higher research degree, for which the most appropriate 
        course is an MPhil If you are looking for a course of this type you 
        should </b><a href="../postgraduate/index.htm"><b>return to the graduate admissions front 
        page</b></a><b> and find out about the Faculty's MPhil courses</b>.</p>
      <p>Candidates work closely with their supervisors, who will usually be assigned 
        to them at the start of the course. It is possible to change supervisors 
        with minimal formality, and it is often desirable to do so as the research 
        project develops.</p>
      <p>Although research students spend long hours working independently, they 
        are also able to attend regular (usually fortnightly) seminars in their 
        subject area. All graduate students are required to be members of a College, 
        which offers a centre of social activity, as well as providing an opportunity 
        to meet graduates who work in other fields.</p>
      <p>All members of the University, including graduate students, are entitled 
        to attend lectures in any Faculty.</p>
      <p>In recent years the Faculty has admitted very few students for this degree. 
        It is generally felt that many candidates would benefit more from a one-year, 
        taught course such as an MPhil, or from a full three year period of 
        research for the <a href="../postgraduate/PhD.htm">PhD</a> In reaching decisions about 
        applications the Degree Committee takes particular account of: </p>
      <ul>
        <li>The applicant's academic record and references </li>
        <li>Their suitability for the proposed course (including knowledge of 
          foreign languages) </li>
        <li>The applicant's research proposal - in particular whether it represents 
          a realistic area of study for completion within two years. </li>
        <li>Whether a suitable supervisor can be found for the proposed research 
        </li>
        <li>The written work which a candidate submits in support of their application 
        </li>
      </ul>
      <p>Applications must be accompanied by a writing sample of 5,000 - 7,000 
        words. Applicants can submit any work they like, but it is worth choosing 
        work which is recent, and which relates to the proposed subject of research, 
        if material of this kind is available. It is probably more important, 
        however, to submit what you consider to be your best work than something 
        which is not your best, but is close to your field of research. Many applicants 
        submit their undergraduate dissertation or similar extended piece of work.</p>
      <p>If you have a particular subject of research in mind, you might wish 
        to visit the list of <a href="http://www.english.cam.ac.uk/people/">Members of the Faculty</a> 
        to see who might be an appropriate supervisor for you. Members of the 
        Faculty may be able to help with enquiries from potential graduate students 
        in their own field.</p>
      <p><span style="font-weight: bold"><strong>*The final deadline for applications for entry in October 2018 is 4 January, 2018.</strong></span><strong>*</strong></p>
      <p>All potential applicants should be aware that in order to be finally 
        accepted for the course it is necessary to be accepted <b>both </b>by 
        the Faculty <b>and </b>by a College. This can favour those who make early 
        applications. </p>
      <hr width="500" align="center">
      <p>Enquiries which relate specifically to the English Faculty can be directed 
      to:</p>
    <p>
      The Director of Graduate Studies<br />
      <em>University of Cambridge<br />
      9 West Road<br />
      Cambridge<br />
      UK<br />
      CB3 9DP</em>
      </p>
<p>
      Tel. 01223 335076 
</p>

      <p><a href="mailto:af285@cam.ac.uk">Contact us</a> if you have any general 
        enquiries about graduate admissions. </p>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}
</style>
<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>

		<div class="row content recessed-content">
			<div class="wrap clearfix">
				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
						<h1>MPhil in English Studies: Eighteenth-Century and Romantic Studies</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" --> <br />
<hr noshade="noshade" color="#0099cc" />
      <ul>
        <li><a href="#introduction">Introduction</a></li>
        <li><a href="#course">The Course</a></li>
        <li><a href="#applications">Entry Requirements and Admissions Procedures</a></li>
      </ul>
      <hr noshade="noshade" color="#0099cc" />
      <h2><a name="introduction" id="introduction"></a>Introduction</h2>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="1" align="right">
        <tr> 
          <td align="center" valign="middle"><img src="images/Ugolino.jpg" width="272" height="208" border="1" /></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td align="center"><font size="-1">Wm. Blake, <em>Ugolino and his Sons 
            in Prison</em>, <br />
            Fitzwilliam Museum</font></td>
        </tr>
      </table>
      <p>This nine-month MPhil introduces postgraduate students to the rich canvas of eighteenth-century and Romantic literature. It offers you the chance to deepen your study of writers as various as Swift, Pope, Fielding, Johnson, Wordsworth, Wollstonecraft, Byron and Scott, alongside some of their less well-known contemporaries, and to explore literary works of the period within broad historical, intellectual and artistic contexts. At the same time, every student on the course pursues an individual research project on a topic of his or her choice associated with the period. The unique resources Cambridge offers to those working on the long eighteenth century include, besides the magnificent University Library (one of the few copyright libraries in the UK), the Pepys Library at Magdalene College, Trinity College’s collection of Milton, Swift and Tennyson manuscripts, Pembroke College’s Smart and Gray papers, rare books and manuscripts associated with Wordsworth and Coleridge held at St John’s and King’s Colleges, and the Fitzwilliam Museum’s unrivalled William Blake collection. Trips to some of these places (the Pepys Library and the Fitzwilliam, for example), and to other venues such as Sir John Soane’s Museum in London, are often features of the MPhil programme.</p>
      <p>Members of the Faculty range widely in their interests but particular research strengths pursued here include literature’s relationship to philosophy and intellectual culture; lyric, and the history, theory and practice of poetic forms; and literature’s interactions with material and visual culture. Amongst the members of the Faculty working on these and many other eighteenth-century and Romantic subjects are: </p>
      <p><a href="/people/Abbott/Ruth/"> Ruth Abbott</a>, <a href="/people/Baxendine/Jamie/">Jamie  Baxendine</a>, <a href="/people/Chirico/Paul/">Paul Chirico</a>, <a href="/people/Collis/Karen/">Karen Collis </a>, <a href="/people/Connell/Philip/">Philip Connell</a>, <a href="/people/DeBolla/Peter/"> Peter de Bolla</a>, <a href="/people/Gonda/Caroline/">Caroline Gonda</a>, <a href="/people/Gorji/Mina/" >Mina Gorji </a>, <a href="/people/Haggarty/Sarah/">Sarah Haggarty</a>, <a href="/people/Hardy/Nicholas/">Nick Hardy</a>, Dr Joseph Hone, <a href="/people/Houghton-Walker/Sarah/">Dr Sarah Houghton-Walker</a>, <a href="/people/Jones/Ewan/">Ewan Jones</a>, <a href="/people/Joy/Louise/">Louise Joy</a>, <a href="/people/McDowell/Stacey/">Stacey McDowell</a>, <a href="/people/Morris/Amy/">Amy Morris</a>, <a href="/people/Owens/Thomas/">Thomas Owens</a>, <a href="/people/Parker/Fred/">Fred Parker</a>, <a href="/people/Read/Sophie/">Sophie Read</a>, <a href="/people/Regan/John/">John Regan</a>, <a href="/people/Russell/Corinna/"> Corinna Russell</a>, <a href="/people/Simonova/Natasha/">Natasha Simonova </a>,<a href="/people/Tilmouth/Christopher/">  Christopher Tilmouth</a>, <a href="/people/Tomalin/Marcus/">Marcus Tomalin</a>, <a href="/people/Toner/Anne/">Anne Toner</a>, <a href="/people/Wallace/Jennifer/"> Jennifer Wallace</a>, <a href="/people/Wilkinson/Hazel/">Hazel Wilkinson</a>, <a href="/people/Wilson/Ross/">Ross Wilson</a></p>
      <p>The MPhil course runs in tandem with an <a href="../../seminars/rom.htm">Eighteenth-Century and Romantic Studies Graduate Research Seminar</a>, which meets fortnightly and is open to all Cambridge students and academics working in this field. Recent and forthcoming guest speakers at this seminar include Professors Karen O’Brien (King’s College, London), James Chandler (University of Chicago), Christine Gerrard (University of Oxford), and Paul Hamilton (Queen Mary, London). We also maintain our own on-line <a href="http://www.english.cam.ac.uk/research/eighteenth/">research hub</a> which keeps students up-to-date with forthcoming events and the latest developments in the field. Other relevant research groups within the Faculty include the <a href ="http://www.english.cam.ac.uk/cmt/">Centre for Material Texts</a> and the <a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/research/johnclare/">Centre for John Clare Studies</a>  </p>
      <h2><a name="course" id="course"></a>The Course</h2>
      <p>Taught seminars (offered by individual Faculty members on their areas of special interest) run throughout the Michaelmas and Lent Terms. Students take two of these each term – four in total. These may all be courses offered by this particular MPhil Alternatively, it’s possible to substitute (in one or both of the first two terms) a course-option from another MPhil in English (that is, the Renaissance Literature, American Literature, Modern and Contemporary Literature, or Criticism and Culture programmes); or, by arrangement, students can sometimes take a course from an MPhil provided by another Faculty entirely.        </p>
      <p>Taught seminar courses offered as part of the Eighteenth-Century and Romantic Studies MPhil change from year to year but have recently included: </p>
      <p>Dr Ruth Abbott, <em><a href="reading/18th Century - Georgic and Didactic Poetry.pdf">Georgic and Didactic Poetry</a></em></p>
      <p>Drs Phil Connell and Mina Gorji, <em><a href="reading/18thCentury-Literature and Popular Culture 1718.pdf">Literature and Popular Culture</a></em> </p>
      <p>Dr Sarah Haggarty, <em><a href="reading/18th Century - Material Cultures.pdf">Moving Things: 
Romantic-period
Material Cultures</a></em></p>
      <p>Dr Fred Parker, <em><a href="reading/18thCentury-WritingtheSelf.pdf">Writing the Self </a></em>
      <p>Drs Fred Parker and Corinna Russell, <em><a href="reading/18th Century - Greece and Rome.pdf">Greece and Rome</a></em></p>
        <p>Dr Natasha Simonova , <em><a href="reading/18th Century - Authors and Readers.pdf">Authors and Readers in the 18th Century </a></em></p>
        <p>Dr Christopher Tilmouth, <em><a href="reading/18th Century - Passion and Sentiment in Enlightenment Thought and Literature.pdf">Passion and Sentiment in Enlightenment Thought and Literature </a></em>
        </p>
        <p>Dr Corinna Russell, <a href="reading/18thCentury-RomanticSongbook.pdf"><em>The Romantic Songbook</em></a></p>
        <p>Dr Louise Joy, <a href="reading/18th Century - Education.Freedom.pdf"><em>Education and Freedom</em></a></p>
        </p>
      <table border="0" cellpadding="1" align="left">
        <tr> 
          <td width="400" align="center" valign="middle"><img src="images/elegy.jpg" width="366" height="193" border="1" /></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td align="center" valign="middle"><font size="-1">Gray's Elegy, Pembroke 
            College</font></td>
        </tr>
  </table>
      <p>In addition to our taught courses, a separate set of classes and workshops provides MPhil students with an introduction to research skills, electronic resources, and critical approaches. Our students can also attend other lectures and seminars within the English Faculty and in related Faculties such as History, Classics, Modern Languages, History of Art, Philosophy, and History and Philosophy of Science.        </p>
      <p>Collectively, the taught seminars offer both a common core of period-based study and the opportunity for individuals to choose from a varied and interdisciplinary menu. Within the framework of the courses, students are able both to develop their own interests and to focus their whole scheme of work either more sharply or more adventurously, as they please. The MPhil programme as a whole also fosters a strong sense of community and collaborative exchange. This is particularly evident in the graduate conferences put on in the final term of the course under the auspices of the English Faculty, but organised and run by graduates for graduates. This combination of individual flexibility and intellectual community is one of the great strengths of the MPhil        </p>
      <table width="226" border="0" align="right" cellpadding="1">
        <tr> 
          <td align="center" valign="middle"><img src="images/Byron1.jpg" width="205" height="277" border="1" /></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td height="20" align="center" valign="middle"><font size="-1">Byron, 
            Trinity College</font></td>
        </tr>
      </table>
     <p><strong>Examined Work</strong> </p>
     <p>• Two coursework essays, each of not more than 5,000 words. One of the essays to be written for one of the chosen Michaelmas Term courses, the other essay written for one of the chosen Lent term courses. The first essay contributes 20% and the second essay 30% to the overall degree mark. In Easter term the teaching will be centred around supervisions for the dissertation. Supervision for each coursework essay consists of a half-hour one-on-one meeting with the leader of the seminar/course for which you are writing your essay. Drafts or outlines of up to 750 words can be submitted in advance of that meeting.</p>
     <p>
       • A dissertation of 12,000 to 15,000 words on a research topic of your choice, contributing 50% to the overall mark. Students work on the dissertation throughout the nine months of the course, in consultation with their personal supervisor. At the end of the Michaelmas Term, students are required to submit an essay of 2,200 to 2,500 words on a topic directly related to the dissertation, which they have devised in consultation with their supervisor. This essay is a formative exercise and does not contribute to the overall mark. The dissertation provides the main focus of each student's work between April and June. It serves as the culmination of the year’s intellectual journey and offers you the chance to investigate a subject that particularly appeals to you. </p>
     
      

      

      <h2><a name="applications" id="applications"></a>Entry Requirements and Admissions 
        Procedures</h2>
      <p>You may find it helpful to find out about <a 
      href="Funding_Home.htm">funding for home 
        students</a> or <a 
      href="Funding_OS.htm">funding for 
        overseas students</a> before you apply.
        </p><div align="left">
                    <table border="0" cellpadding="1" align="left">
          <tr> 
            <td width="290" align="center" valign="middle"><img src="images/Hogarth.jpg" width="252" height="283" border="1" /></td>
          </tr>
          <tr> 
            <td align="center" valign="middle"><font size="-1">William Hogarth, 
              detail of <em>The Bench</em>, <br />
              Fitzwilliam Museum</font></td>
          </tr>
        </table>
      </div>
      <p align="left">&nbsp;</p>
      <p align="left">All graduate students in Cambridge are members of a College 
        as well as of a Faculty of the University, and those applying through 
        the <a 
      href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/univ/gsprospectus/request_form/index.cgi">Graduate Admission website</a> for a place on the course will find themselves 
        invited to list a number of Colleges in order of preference. It is a good 
        idea to consult the <a 
      href="http://www.cam.ac.uk/CambUniv/Finding/Addresses/college.html">prospectuses 
          of a number of Colleges</a> before you apply.      </p>
      <p>All  applications must be made using the online  <strong>Applicant Portal</strong> on the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/students/gradadmissions/prospec/apply">Graduate Admissions Office</a> website. It is important  that you read through the information available on this website before submitting your application. If you are  seeking funding for your course, there are specific deadlines and eligibility  criteria for each funding competition. Please check the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/students/studentregistry/fees/funding/index.html">Student Registry funding webpages</a> for details of eligibility and the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/students/gradadmissions/prospec/apply/deadlines.html">Application and Funding Deadlines</a> section of the Graduate Admissions  Office website for application deadlines. </p>
    <p>Please note that after   submitting your online application form, there may be a delay of up to   48 hours before you are able to access your self-service account and   submit supporting documentation.</p>
<p align="left">Applications are first considered by the Faculty. Potential supervisors 
        are then consulted. Successful applications are then offered to the Colleges 
        of the student's choice, and may be then passed on to the second or third 
        choice. </p>
<p align="left"><strong>*The final deadline for applications for entry in October 2018 is 4 January, 2018.*</strong>
<p>Most of our graduate students have a first-class undergraduate degree or  international equivalent. The Faculty is willing in principle to accept  candidates with strong 2.1s, or mature students who have not pursued an  orthodox pattern of higher education, provided that such applicants have strong  backing from their referees, have a feasible topic, and are well qualified for  their proposed course of research. We recognise both that things sometimes do  not go candidates’ way in examinations and that a sparkling examination style  is not always the best qualification for graduate work. Applicants should note, however, that the  vast majority of those accepted onto the MPhil do have a first class BA  degree or its overseas e quivalent, and the vast majority of students accepted  for the PhD have similarly strong MA marks. Applicants whose first 
        degrees are in other disciplines are always considered, provided they 
        can give an account of how their interest in literary study has developed. 
        We welcome qualified UK, EU, and overseas applicants (those for whom English 
        is not a first language will be required by the Board of Graduate Studies 
      to provide evidence of linguistic proficiency). </p>
<p>Applicants should include specific proposals for advanced study or research 
        (of around 500 words). A piece of written work, of 5,000 - 7,000 words, 
        should accompany a formal application. Applicants may submit any work 
        they like, but it is worth choosing work which is recent and which relates 
        to your proposed area of study, if this is available. Many applicants 
        submit their undergraduate dissertation or similar extended piece of work. You can submit one long piece or several shorter essays if you wish. 
        In reaching decisions about applications the Degree Committee takes particular 
        account of: </p>
      <ul>
        <li><span class="mainbody">The applicant's academic record and references </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">Their suitability for the proposed course (including 
          knowledge of foreign languages) </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">The applicant's research proposal, which should 
          suggest a realistic program of work for a 15,000 word dissertation. </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">Whether a suitable supervisor can be found 
          for the proposed research </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">The written work which a candidate submits 
          in support of their application </span></li>
      </ul>
    <hr />
      <p>Enquiries regarding the course content should be addressed to the  course convenor <a href="mailto:cdjt100@cam.ac.uk">Dr Chris Tilmouth</a>.</p>
      <p>All other queries should be directed to <a href="mailto:af285@cam.ac.uk">Anna  Fox</a> (graduate secretary).</p>
      
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>

<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>

		<div class="row content recessed-content">
			<div class="wrap clearfix">
				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
					<h1>The MPhil in American Literature </h1>	
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->

<hr noshade color="#0099cc" />
    <ul>
        <li><a href="#overview">Course Overview</a></li>
        <li><a href="#study">Course of Study</a></li>
        <li><a href="#faculty">Faculty</a></li>
        <li><a href="#entry">Entry Requirements</a>      </li>
    </ul>
<hr noshade color="#0099cc" />

    <p align="justify"><span class="h2"><b>Course Overview</b><b></b></span><b><a name="overview" id="overview"></a></b>
    <table border="0" align="right">
          <tr> 
            <td><div align="center"><img src="images/MPhil_Info_AmLit.NEW_clip_image006_0000.jpg" alt="Amlit3" width="205" height="157" /></div></td>
        </tr>
          <tr> 
            <td align="center">Alvin Langdon Coburn, <br />
            <em>Brooklyn Bridge</em> c. 1912</p></td>
        </tr>
  </table>
        <p>The  MPhil in American Literature is a nine month course running from October to  June, which provides an intensive foundation in the postgraduate study of  American Literature, and the opportunity to combine this with options from  other MPhil courses in the English Faculty. The course therefore offers  flexible provision for students wishing to specialise in American Literature,  and those who want to explore transatlantic and transnational topics. The emphasis  throughout is on detailed attention to literary texts in their historical and  intellectual contexts. The MPhil equips students with advanced research  skills and fosters individual choice in research focus, methodology, and  critical approach. </p>
        <p>          Teaching  consists of compulsory Foundation and Research Methods courses, followed by optional  seminar courses. Throughout the three terms, MPhil students pursue individual  dissertation projects under the guidance of a supervisor with whom they arrange  a programme of one-to-one supervisions. The course is assessed by essays in  each of the first two terms, and the dissertation submitted at the end of the  third term. MPhil students are required to attend graduate research seminars  and are free to attend undergraduate lectures in the English Faculty, and  elsewhere in the University. </p>
        <p>          Graduate  research in Cambridge is greatly facilitated by the holdings of the University  Library, one of only five copyright libraries in the United Kingdom, which is  supplemented by the English Faculty Library as well as libraries within  individual colleges.</p>
    <p>      <table border="0" align="left">
        <tr> 
          <td><div align="center"><img src="images/MPhil_Info_AmLit.NEW_clip_image002_0000.jpg" /></div></td>
      </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td align="center">Albert Bierstadt<br />
            <em>In the Mountains</em> (1867)</p></td>
      </tr>
  </table>    Faculty  members whose research and teaching interests include American Literature are listed below.  Their interests range widely in American  literature from the seventeenth to the twenty-first centuries, and include  early American writing, especially puritan poetry, diaries and  autobiography, natural history, and transatlantic polemic; nineteenth-century literature and  culture including popular theatre, especially melodrama, African American  writing, the novel, Transcendentalism; twentieth-century writing especially  modernist and experimental poetry, the Harlem Renaissance, magazine and  periodical cultures; contemporary writing including  postwar fiction, sports writing, and the short  story. We welcome dissertation proposals on any topic in American Literature,  including transatlantic and comparative&nbsp; projects.<br />
        </p>
    <p>While  some students take the MPhil as a free-standing Master’s qualification, many  go on to PhD research in Cambridge and elsewhere. Under normal circumstances,  students will not be permitted to register for PhD research in American or  Anglo-American subjects unless they have completed the MPhil in American  Literature (or a similar postgraduate course) at an appropriate standard.</span>          </p>
    <p>&nbsp;</p>
    <p align="justify"><span class="h2"><b>The Course</b></span><b><a name="study" id="study"></a></b><table border="0" align="right">
        <tr> 
          <td width="172"><div align="center"><img src="images/MPhil_Info_AmLit.DayofDoom.jpg" width="172" height="231" align="left" /></div></td>
      </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td align="center">Michael Wigglesworth <br/><em>The Day of Doom</em> (1662)</span></p>
          </em></td>
      </tr>
    </table>
    <tr> 
      <td width="207"><div align="center"></div></td>
      </tr>
        
        
    
    </table>
      <p>Seminar  courses run in the first two terms, Michaelmas and Lent. The Michaelmas term’s  Foundation and Research Methods courses are compulsory; in the Lent term  students choose two from a range of optional courses.
      <p><strong>      Michaelmas Term: Foundation  Course in American Literature</strong><br />
     The Foundation course is intensively team-taught in two ninety-minute seminars per week over 6 weeks. The two seminars in any particular week are closely connected, so that conversations develop from one meeting to the next. From week to week through the term the sequence of seminars is chronological, while also encouraging comparative engagement between periods. The course as a whole is balanced in terms of canonical and less canonical texts, and as far as genre and critical approach are concerned. The following outline for 2016-17 is illustrative:

      <p><table border="0" align="left">
        <tr> 
          <td width="200"><div align="center"><img src="images/MPhil_Info_AmLit.Chaplin.jpg"  width="243" height="191"  /></div></td>
      </tr><tr><td align="center"> Charlie Chaplin<br/><em>Modern Times</em> (1936)</td></tr></table>Week 1:	American Puritans, Lyric and narrative        <br/>
      Week 2:	‘The Americas’: Race, Slavery, Genre <br/>
        Week 3:	Henry James, New York, Photography <br/>
        Week 4:	Modernism, Home and Homelessness <br/>
        Week 5:	World War II Writing<br/>
        Week 6:	American (or World?) Fiction in the 21st Century
      <p>
        
        Full course details and reading lists are provided to successful applicants on admission.             
      <p><strong>Lent Term 2017 pooled options  </strong>      
<p>MPhil students choose two optional courses, each consisting of six ninety-minute seminars, from the pool shared with the Modern and Contemporary, Criticism and Culture, and 18th Century and Romantic Studies M.Phils. In 2017-18 the American M. Phil. will offer the following two courses to this pool, for which its students have priority:  </p>

<table border="0" align="right">
        <tr> 
          <td width="207"><div align="center"><img src="images/MPhil_Info_AmLit.ToomerCane.jpg" width="133" height="210" /></div></td>
      </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td align="center">Jean Toomer <br/></em>Cane (1923)</td>
      </tr>
    </table>

<p><strong>Dr. Kasia Boddy</strong><br/>
  <em>The African American Novel Since 1900</em><br/> This series of seminars will consider the evolution of the African American novel through the twentieth and into the twenty-first century. It will explore literature’s engagement with the political, social and psychological consequences of American racism, and consider shifting debates about cultural nationalism and universalism. Considering development and undercutting of specific movements and traditions (the Harlem Renaissance, the Black Arts Movement), the seminars will examine fiction’s relation to other art forms (music, film, comedy) and intellectual disciplines (ethnography) as well the varied contexts of its production, publication and reception.  </p>
</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<table border="0" align="left">
        <tr> 
          <td width="200"><div align="center"><img src="images/MPhil_Info_AmLit.Cornell.jpg"  width="243" height="191"  /></div></td>
      </tr><tr><td align ="center"> Joseph Cornell<br/> Untitled (1945)</td></tr></table><p><strong>Dr Edward Allen</strong><br/> 
  <em>American Things</em><br/> This course will trace the shifting fortunes and future prospects of Thing Theory, discovering ways to critique as well as apply the thinking of Barthes, Brown, Benjamin and others to a variety of works, from novels to short stories, art installations to poems. In what sense might a novelist render something legible? What kinds of things can poems accommodate? What happens when we turn the stuff we’ve always talked about into subject matter? The six-week series will focus mostly on modernist practice, though students will be encouraged to present texts of their own choosing for discussion. Topics and authors will include: ‘Tools’: Norris, Dos Passos; ‘Gifts’: Moore, Pound; ‘Foodstuffs’: Brooks, O’Hara; ‘Objets Trouvés’: Stein, Cornell.  
</p>
<p><strong>Research Methods</strong><br/> A fortnightly ninety-minute class attending to such matters as scholarly method, electronic resources, editing and editions, and academic conferences. This compulsory course is not formally assessed. </p>
  
<p><strong>Throughout the Year</strong><br />
  M.  Phil. Students work on the dissertation topics proposed in their applications  with a supervisor appointed on admission. A programme of one-to-one  supervisions is arranged between the student and supervisor.<br />
  In  addition to taught seminars and dissertation supervisions, MPhil students are  expected to attend at least ten sessions from a wide range of graduate literary  research seminars that feature papers from graduates, Faculty staff and invited  speakers. Among these, the American Literature Research Seminar meets  fortnightly in the Michaelmas and Lent terms, and organises a one-day symposium  for graduate students in the Easter term. </td>
        </p>
        <p><strong>Examined Work</strong> </p>
          <ul>
            <li>Two coursework essays, each of not more than 5,000 words. One of the essays to be written for the Michaelmas Term Foundation Course, the other essay written for one of the chosen Lent term courses. The first essay contributes 20% and the second essay 30% to the overall degree mark. In Easter term the teaching will be centred around supervisions for the dissertation. Supervision for each coursework essay consists of a half-hour one-on-one meeting with the leader of the seminar/course for which you are writing your essay. Drafts or outlines of up to 750 words can be submitted in advance of that meeting.            </li><br/>
            <li> A dissertation of 12,000 to 15,000 words on the research topic of your choice (which must fall within the scope of American and related literatures), contributing 50% to the overall mark. Students work on the dissertation throughout the nine months of the course, in consultation with their personal supervisor. At the end of the Michaelmas Term, students are required to submit an essay of 2,200 to 2,500 words on a topic directly related to the dissertation, which they have devised in consultation with their supervisor. This essay is a formative exercise and does not contribute to the overall mark. </li>
        </ul>            
          <p align="justify"><span class="h2"><b>Faculty</b><b></b></span><b><a name="faculty" id="faculty"></a></b>       
<p align="justify">Faculty members whose teaching or research interests 
        include American topics:
        <table width="90%" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3"> 
        <tr> 
          <td width="30%"><a href="/people/Allen/Edward/"> Dr Edward Allen</a></td>
          <td width="32%"><a href="/people/Houen/Alex/">Dr Alex Houen</a></td>
          <td width="28%"><a href="/people/Morris/Amy/">Dr Amy Morris</a></td>
        </tr>
        <tr> 
          <td><a href= "/people/Boddy/Kasia/">Dr Kasia Boddy</a></td>

          Ian Patterson</a></td>
        </tr><tr>

      </table>
    <br/>
    <p align="justify">Further information is available on this server about 
        these and other <a href="/people/">members of the Faculty.</a></p>
   <p align="justify"><span class="h2"><b>Entry requirements and application procedure</b></span><b><a name="entry" id="entry"></a></b>
      </h1>
</p>
    <p>You may find it helpful to find out about <a 
      href="Funding_Home.htm">funding for home 
        students</a> or <a 
      href="Funding_OS.htm">funding for 
        overseas students</a> before you apply.  All graduate students in Cambridge are members of a College 
        as well as of a Faculty of the University, and those applying through 
        the <a 
      href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/univ/gsprospectus/request_form/index.cgi">Graduate Admission website</a> for a place on the course will find themselves 
        invited to list a number of Colleges in order of preference. It is a good 
        idea to consult the <a 
      href="http://www.cam.ac.uk/CambUniv/Finding/Addresses/college.html">prospectuses 
    of a number of Colleges</a> before you apply. </p>
<p>All  applications must be made using the online  <strong>Applicant Portal</strong> on the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/students/gradadmissions/prospec/apply">Graduate Admissions Office</a> website. It is important  that you read through the information available on this website before submitting your application. If you are  seeking funding for your course, there are specific deadlines and eligibility  criteria for each funding competition. Please check the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/students/studentregistry/fees/funding/index.html">Student Registry funding webpages</a> for details of eligibility and the <a href="http://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/students/gradadmissions/prospec/apply/deadlines.html">Application and Funding Deadlines</a> section of the Graduate Admissions  Office website for application deadlines. </p>
<p>Please note that after   submitting your online application form, there may be a delay of up to   48 hours before you are able to access your self-service account and   submit supporting documentation.</p>
<p>Applications are first considered by the Faculty. Potential supervisors 
        are then consulted. Successful applications are then offered to the Colleges 
        of the student's choice, and may be then passed on to the second or third 
        choice. </p>
      <p><strong>*The final deadline for applications for entry in October 2018 is 4 January, 2018.*</strong></p>
<p>Most of our graduate students have a first-class undergraduate degree or  international equivalent. The Faculty is willing in principle to accept  candidates with strong 2.1s, or mature students who have not pursued an  orthodox pattern of higher education, provided that such applicants have strong  backing from their referees, have a feasible topic, and are well qualified for  their proposed course of research. We recognise both that things sometimes do  not go candidates’ way in examinations and that a sparkling examination style  is not always the best qualification for graduate work. Applicants should note, however, that the  vast majority of those accepted onto the MPhil do have a first class BA  degree or its overseas equivalent, and the vast majority of students accepted  for the PhD have similarly strong MA marks.  Applicants whose first 
  degrees are in other disciplines are always considered, provided they 
  can give an account of how their interest in literary study has developed. 
  We welcome qualified UK, EU, and overseas applicants (those for whom English 
  is not a first language will be required by the Graduate Admissions office  
  to provide evidence of linguistic proficiency). </p>
    <p>Applicants should include specific proposals for advanced study or research 
        (of around 500 words). A piece of written work, of 5,000 - 7,000 words, 
        should accompany a formal application. Applicants may submit any work 
        they like, but it is worth choosing work which is recent and which relates 
        to your proposed area of study, if this is available. Many applicants 
        submit their undergraduate dissertation or similar extended piece of work.You can submit one long piece or several shorter essays if you wish. 
        In reaching decisions about applications the Degree Committee takes particular 
        account of: </p>
      <ul>
        <li><span class="mainbody">The applicant's academic record and references 
          </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">Their suitability for the proposed course (including 
          knowledge of foreign languages) </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">The applicant's research proposal, which should 
          suggest a realistic program of work for a 15,000 word dissertation. 
          </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">Whether a suitable supervisor can be found 
          for the proposed research </span> </li>
        <li><span class="mainbody">The written work which a candidate submits 
          in support of their application </span></li>
      </ul>
      <hr />
       <p>Enquiries regarding the course content should be addressed to the  course convenor <a href="mailto:fmg20@cam.ac.uk">Dr Fiona Green
       </a>.</p>
      <p>All other queries should be directed to <a href="mailto:af285@cam.ac.uk">Anna  Fox</a> (graduate secretary).</p>
      <address>
      </address>
      <p>&nbsp;</p>
    <p>&nbsp;</p>

<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>
