		<div class="row content recessed-content">
			<div class="wrap clearfix">
				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
					<h1 style="display:inline;">Eighteenth Century and Romantic Studies</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->
<p> <strong>Michaelmas Term 2017 </strong>
<p>Thursdays, 5-6.30pm in the Board Room, Faculty of English
<p><strong>19 October </strong><br/>	
  Dr Phil Connell (University of Cambridge)<br/>		
  Wordsworth's "Sonnets Dedicated to Liberty", and the British Revolutionary Past
<p><strong>2 November</strong><br/>
	Prof Nigel Leask (University of Glasgow)  <br/>	 	Dr Johnson after Pennant: The (Re)transit of Caledonia
  <p><strong>23 November</strong><br/>		Dr Paul Davis (UCL)<br/>	Joseph Addison and Poetic Reluctance
    
  <p><!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

						
				  </div> <!-- end content container -->
				</div> <!-- end column9 maincontent -->
				<div class="column3 secondary-content">
				  <div class="content-container">
				    <div class="heading-container">
					<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="RelatedLinksTitle" -->							
                       <h2>Related Links</h2>
					   <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
				    </div><!-- end heading container -->
					  
                      <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="RelatedLinks" -->
	<ul class="unstyled-list related-links">
    <li><a href="/research/collaborative.htm">Collaborative Research Projects</a></li>
    <li><a href="/research/groups.htm">Faculty Research Groups</a></li>
    <li><a href="/seminars/index.htm">Graduate Research Seminars</a>
	<ul style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:hanging;">
	    <li style="padding:0;"><a href="/seminars/amlit/index.htm">American</a></li>
	    <li style="padding:0;"><a href="/seminars/rom.htm">18th Century and Romantic Studies</a></li>
	    <li style="padding:0;"><a href="/seminars/med.htm">Middle English</a></li>
	    <li style="padding:0;"><a href="/seminars/nineteenth.htm">Nineteenth-Century</a></li>	
	    <li style="padding:0;"><a href="https://www.hist.cam.ac.uk/seminars/early-modern-interdisciplinary">Interdisciplinary Early Modern </a></li>
	    <li style="padding:0;"><a href="parl.htm">Postcolonial and Related Literatures</a></li>	
	    <li style="padding:0;"><a href="/seminars/queercultures.html">Queer Cultures</a></li>
    	<li style="padding:0;"><a href="/seminars/rgs/index.htm">Renaissance</a></li>
    	<li style="padding:0;"><a href="http://www.mml.cam.ac.uk/film/research/seminars">Screen Media </a><img src="/images/interface/icon-external-link.png" width="9" height="9" /></li>
    	<li style="padding:0;"><a href="./song/">Song</a> </li>
    	<li style="padding:0;"><a href="TheoryCC.htm">Theory, Criticism, and Culture</a></li>
    	<li style="padding:0;"><a href="/seminars/twentieth.htm">Twentieth Century and Contemporary Literature</a></li>
   	  </ul>
    </li>
    <li>Other Research Groups</li>
		<ul style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:hanging;">
  			<li style="padding:0;"><a href="http://www.marginalia.co.uk/">The Medieval Reading Group</a> <img src="/images/interface/icon-external-link.png" width="9" height="9" /></li>
  		</ul>
    </li>
  <li><a href="/research/features/index.htm">Research Features</a></li>
    <li><a href="/research/intranet/index.htm">Research Funding</a> <span style="font-size:80%;">(Raven Needed)</span></li>
    <li><a href="/research/intranet/access.htm">Open Access</a> <span style="font-size:80%;">(Raven Needed)</span></li>
    <li><a href="/research/intranet/impact/">Research Impact</a> <span style="font-size:80%;">(Raven Needed)</span></li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
                      <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}
</style>
<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>

				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
						<h1 style="display:inline;">Twentieth Century and Contemporary Literature</h1>
                        <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->

    <p><strong>Thursday 12 Octobe</strong>r: 4.30-6.00 in S-R24, Faculty of English <br/>
      [joint seminar with American Literature Seminar]<br/>
      
      Joy Porter (Hull) - "The Native American Indian Poet of the First World War: Trauma, Modernity and the Bloomsbury/Garsington Set"
      
</p>
    <p><strong>Tuesday, 17 October</strong> 5-6.30pm in S-R24, Faculty of English - THIS SEMINAR HAS BEEN CANCELLED<br/>Andrea Brady (Queen Mary) - "Poets in the Wake: Sean Bonney, Dionne Brand, NourbeSe Philips"</p>
    <p><strong>Tuesday, 31</strong> <strong>October</strong>: 5-6.30pm S-R24, Faculty of English<br/>
      
      Scarlett Baron (UCL) - "Literature as Algorithmic Variation: The Implications of Darwin's 'Universal Acid'"
      
      4) </p>
    <p><strong>Tuesday, 14 November</strong>: 5-6.30pm S-R24, Faculty of English
      
      Keston Sutherland (University of Sussex) <br/>
      "Poetry's Specific Pain"</p> 
	<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}

<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>

	<header id="branding" role="banner">
			<hgroup>
				<h1 id="site-title"><span><a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/" rel="home">The Manuscripts Lab</a></span></h1>
				<h2 id="site-description">For the research and pedagogy of handwritten culture</h2>
			</hgroup>

						<a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/">
									<img src="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/cropped-CUL-MSDAR-185-9.jpg" width="1000" height="288" alt="The Manuscripts Lab" />

<article id="post-462" class="post-462 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">London Medieval Manuscripts Seminar:  Programme 2016/7</h1>

				<div class="entry-meta">
			<span class="sep">Posted on </span><a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/london-medieval-manuscripts-seminar-programme-20167/" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date" datetime="2016-10-04T05:30:53+00:00">4 October 2016</time></a><span class="by-author"> <span class="sep"> by </span> <span class="author vcard"><a class="url fn n" href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/author/admin/" rel="author">admin</a></span></span>		</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
			</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p class="p1" style="text-align: center;">Institute of English Studies, School of Advanced Study, University of London</p>
<p class="p2" style="text-align: center;"><b>Medieval Manuscripts Seminar: </b><b>Programme 2016/7</b></p>
<p class="p3"> 11 October 2016</p>
<p class="p3"> Andrew Dunning, British Library</p>
<p class="p4"><b>Manuscript Collaboration between Malmesbury and Cirencester Abbeys</b></p>
<p class="p4">From the 1130s to the 1240s, a continual exchange in manuscripts supported the communities of the Benedictine abbey in Malmesbury and the Augustinian abbey in Cirencester. Robert of Cricklade, a canon at Cirencester, wrote of his admiration of William of Malmesbury and his efforts to have copies of several of his works made for the abbey library. Also at Cirencester, Walter de Melida, a scribe and textual critic, used Malmesbury manuscripts for copies of John of Salisbury&#8217;s<i> Policraticus</i> and Alan of Tewkesbury&#8217;s collection of the letters of Thomas Becket. After the death of Cirencester&#8217;s most famous author, Alexander Neckam, in 1217, the prior of Malmesbury provided Walter with a statement of his admiration for Alexander&#8217;s <i>Corrogationes Promethei</i>, likely supporting an effort to assemble Alexander’s complete works. In the 1240s, Alexander&#8217;s nephew, Geoffrey Brito, compiled a miscellany of his uncle&#8217;s works, <i>Sol meldunensis</i>, dedicating it to Geoffrey, abbot of Malmesbury, with an invitation for further contributions. The manuscript appears to have been passed between the two abbeys, with new features added along the way.</p>
<p class="p3">22 November 2016</p>
<p class="p3">Mary Wellesley, British Library</p>
<p class="p4"><b>Graphical Reverence and Script Hierarchy in the manuscript of the N-town Plays</b></p>
<p class="p4">The paper examines the macaronic text of the Magnificat from the ‘Visit to Elizabeth’ pageant in London, British Library, Cotton MS Vespasian D. VIII  &#8212; the sole surviving copy of the Middle English play cycle, The N-town Plays. It explores what the scribe’s use of a script hierarchy has to tell us about performance and reading, and the interplay between liturgy and drama.</p>
<p class="p3"> 31 January 2017</p>
<p class="p3">Ainoa Correa Castro, Marie Curie Postdoctoral Research Fellow, King’s College London</p>
<p class="p4"><b>The scribes of the Silos Apocalypse (London, British Library, Add. MS. 11695) and the scriptorium of Silos in the late eleventh century</b></p>
<p class="p4">In the late eleventh century Fortunio, abbot of the newly restored Benedictine community of Silos, near Burgos, commissioned the time- and cost-consuming task of replicating for the monastery one of the most significant best-sellers of the peninsular Middle Ages: a Beatus. In doing so, he was continuing a long-lasting Iberian, Mozarabic, tradition originating in the late eighth century. In this seminar the Silos Apocalypse will be examined with the purpose of unveiling who were the scribes who intervened in its copying, what can be known about their professional connections, what was their cultural context, and how this codex fits within the written production of Silos in the late eleventh and early twelfth centuries.</p>
<p class="p3"> 7 February 2017</p>
<p class="p3">Arianna D’Ottone Rambach, Associate Professor of Arabic Language and Literature, Palaeography, Codicology and Numismatics – Sapienza, University of Rome</p>
<p class="p4"><b>Arabic Palaeography: Mediterranean contacts and influences</b></p>
<p class="p4">Bilingual and digraphic manuscript-witnesses, papyri, manuscripts and gems, in Greek and Arabic, and Latin and Arabic, offer the opportunity to explore cultural interactions between Mediterranean written practices, and connections between book cultures. A recently discovered, and unique document in Arabic, written in Latin letters, will be also presented and put in context from both the historical and linguistic points of view.</p>
<p class="p3"> 14 March 2017</p>
<p class="p3">David Rundle, University of Oxford</p>
<p class="p4"><b>English Humanist Script in England: the first ten years</b></p>
<p class="p5">In the last half century, the outline of the early development in Florence of humanist bookhand, littera antiqua, has been amassed in detail. Central to this was the work of A. C. de la Mare, who also reconstructed the history of that script in England. This paper revisits that topic and reveals the identity of the first known humanist scribe at work in England. The intention, however, is not simply to add to the sum of knowledge about humanism’s reception beyond the European mainland but also to question the established narratives about its spread from its Italian centre to the periphery.</p>
<p class="p6"> 28 March 2017</p>
<p class="p7">Ralph Hanna III (Emeritus Fellow, Keble College, Oxford)</p>
<p class="p7"><b>Cambridge, University Library, MS. Dd.1.17</b></p>
<p class="p7"><b> </b></p>
<p class="p8">Venue: Dr Seng T Lee Centre for Manuscript and Book Studies,<br />
Senate House Library, University of London,<br />
Malet Street, London WC1E 7HU<br />
All meetings at 5.30 p.m., Tuesdays, followed by a wine reception.<br />
Organiser: Julia Crick, King’s College London.</p>

<div class="twitter-share"><a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.english.cam.ac.uk%2Fmanuscriptslab%2Flondon-medieval-manuscripts-seminar-programme-20167%2F&#038;via=manuscriptslab" class="twitter-share-button">Tweet</a></div>
			</div><!-- .entry-content -->

<article id="post-481" class="post-481 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events category-fourteenth-century">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">London Medieval Manuscripts Seminar</h1>

				<div class="entry-meta">
			<span class="sep">Posted on </span><a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/london-medieval-manuscripts-seminar/" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date" datetime="2017-03-23T22:28:29+00:00">23 March 2017</time></a><span class="by-author"> <span class="sep"> by </span> <span class="author vcard"><a class="url fn n" href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/author/admin/" rel="author">admin</a></span></span>		</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
			</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p class="p1">28 Mar 2017, 17:30 to 28 Mar 2017, 19:00</p>
<p class="p3">Dr Seng T Lee Centre for Manuscript and Book Studies, Senate House Library, Malet Street, London WC1E 7HU</p>
<p class="p4"><b>Ralph Hanna III (Emeritus Fellow, Keble College, Oxford)</b></p>
<p>Cambridge, University Library, MS. Dd.1.17</p>
<p class="p4">Professor Hanna will discuss the medieval and post-medieval history of this compendious collection of Latin and Middle English historical writing and other literature.</p>
<p class="p5">All welcome.</p>
<p class="p5">Further details: http://www.ies.sas.ac.uk/events/event/7273</p>

<div class="twitter-share"><a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.english.cam.ac.uk%2Fmanuscriptslab%2Flondon-medieval-manuscripts-seminar%2F&#038;via=manuscriptslab" class="twitter-share-button">Tweet</a></div>
			</div><!-- .entry-content -->

					</nav><!-- #nav-single -->

					
<article id="post-353" class="post-353 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-events">
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Middle English Graduate Seminar (Lent 2016)</h1>

				<div class="entry-meta">
			<span class="sep">Posted on </span><a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/middle-english-graduate-seminar-lent-2016-2/" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date" datetime="2016-01-15T12:07:15+00:00">15 January 2016</time></a><span class="by-author"> <span class="sep"> by </span> <span class="author vcard"><a class="url fn n" href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/author/bernardo-s-hinojosa/" rel="author">Bernardo Hinojosa</a></span></span>		</div><!-- .entry-meta -->
			</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p>The Middle English Graduate Seminar will meet in the Board Room at the English Faculty, University of Cambridge (9 West Road) on alternate Wednesdays throughout Lent term. Papers begin promptly at 5.15, followed by drinks and questions. Biscuits will be available in the Board Room from <span class="aBn" tabindex="0" data-term="goog_317722213"><span class="aQJ">4.45p.m.</span></span>, so please bring along a mug of tea and catch up with fellow medievalists. After the paper all are welcome to join the speaker for dinner in a nearby restaurant. For any enquiries beforehand, please contact Alex da Costa (ad666@cam.ac.uk).</p>
<p>Among this term&#8217;s seminars, the following examine medieval handwritten cultures:</p>
<p><span class="aBn" tabindex="0" data-term="goog_317722214"><span class="aQJ">20 January</span></span>, <a href="http://www.ncl.ac.uk/elll/staff/profile/aditi.nafde" target="_blank">Aditi Nafde</a> (University of Newcastle): ‘From Print to Manuscript’</p>
<p><span class="aBn" tabindex="0" data-term="goog_317722217"><span class="aQJ">2 March</span></span>, <a href="http://www.rug.nl/staff/s.i.sobecki/research" target="_blank">Sebastian Sobecki</a> (University of Groningen): ‘The Southwark Connection: Gower, Chaucer, and the Writing of <i>The Canterbury Tales’ </i></p>
<p>Full schedule available <a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/research/medieval/?page_id=5">here</a>.</p>

<div class="twitter-share"><a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.english.cam.ac.uk%2Fmanuscriptslab%2Fmiddle-english-graduate-seminar-lent-2016-2%2F&#038;via=manuscriptslab" class="twitter-share-button">Tweet</a></div>
			</div><!-- .entry-content -->

	<footer class="entry-meta">
		This entry was posted in <a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/category/events/" rel="category tag">Events</a> by <a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/author/bernardo-s-hinojosa/">Bernardo Hinojosa</a>. Bookmark the <a href="https://www.english.cam.ac.uk/manuscriptslab/middle-english-graduate-seminar-lent-2016-2/" rel="bookmark">permalink</a>.		
			</footer><!-- .entry-meta -->
</article><!-- #post-353 -->

		<div class="wrap clearfix page-sub-title recessed-sub-title">

		<div class="row content recessed-content">
			<div class="wrap clearfix">
				<div class="column9  main-content" id="content">
					<div class="content-container">
                    <!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="PageTitle" -->
                    <h1>Poetics Before Modernity</h1>
					<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
	<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content" -->

<div class="carousel-container">
	<ul class="unstyled-list slides">
		<li class="slide column12">
			<div class="image-container">
				<img alt="Poetics Before Modernity" title=""  src="../research/images/gallery/poetics-modernity.jpg" class="scale-with-grid"  style="padding:1.2em 0;" />
			</div>
		</li>
	</ul>
</div>
&nbsp;<br />
<p><em>Poetics before Modernity</em> brings together leading classicists, medievalists, and Renaissance scholars to present new work on Western literary theory from antiquity to 1700.</p>
<p>Unless otherwise noted, meetings will take place on <strong>Tuesdays</strong> at <strong>5.15pm</strong> in the <strong>Old Combination Room at Trinity College</strong>. Refreshments will be served.</p>

<p>Convenors: Vladimir Brljak (vb276@cam.ac.uk) and Micha Lazarus (mdsl3@cam.ac.uk). </p>

<p>Please sign up to the mailing list <a href="https://lists.cam.ac.uk/mailman/listinfo/english-poetics">here</a>.</p>
<!--
<h2 class="center" style="padding-top:1.5em;">Next Seminar</h2>
<div id="next">-->
<!-- put text here -->
<!--</div>-->

<h2 style="padding-top:1.5em;">Full Programme: 2016-2017</h2>
<div class="splitcontentleft">
	<p><strong>MICHAELMAS 2016  </strong></p>
	<p>Tuesday 25 Oct. - "<a href="./poetics/index.html#most">Allegory and Etymology</a>"<br/>Glenn Most (Scuola Normale Superiore, Pisa)  </p>
	<p>Thursday 24 Nov. - &quot;<a href="./poetics/index.html#copeland">An Emotional Anthology of Style</a>&quot;<br/>
	  Rita Copeland (University of Pennsylvania)  </p>
	<p><strong>LENT 2017  </strong></p>
	<p>Tuesday 24 Jan.
	 - &quot;<a href="./poetics/index.html#burrow">Practical Criticism, Elizabethan Style</a>&quot;<br/> Colin Burrow (University of Oxford)</p>
	<p> Tuesday 7 Feb. - <a href="./poetics/index.html#halliwell">Inside and Outside the Mind: The Greek Poetics of Inspiration</a><br/> Stephen Halliwell (University of St Andrews)  </p>
	<p>Tuesday 21 Feb.
	  - <a href="./poetics/index.html#whitman">The Second Greatest Story Ever Told</a><br/> Jon Whitman (The Hebrew University of Jerusalem)  </p>
	<p>Tuesday 7 Mar. 
	  <a href="./poetics/index.html#alexander">Lyric Poetics?</a><br/>Gavin Alexander (University of Cambridge)  </p>
</div>
<div class="splitcontentright">
	<p><strong>EASTER 2017  </strong></p>
	<p>Tuesday 2 May. - <a href="./poetics/index.html#greene">Metametrica: Juan Caramuel's Baroque Poetics</a><br/>
	  Roland Greene (Stanford University)  </p>
	<p>Tuesday 16 May. - <a href="./poetics/index.html#struck">Hermeneutic Fields in Ancient Poetics</a><br/>
	  Peter Struck (University of Pennsylvania)  </p>
	<p>Tuesday 30 May. - <a href="./poetics/index.htm#zeeman">Personification and Alienation: The Case of Deguileville</a><br/>
	  Nicolette Zeeman (University of Cambridge)  </p>
	<p>Tuesday 13 Jun.
	  - <a href="./poetics/index.html#eden">The Early Modern Rhetoric of Plato's Poetics</a><br/>Kathy Eden (Columbia University)  </p>
</div>
<br clear="all" />
	<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->

						
				  </div> <!-- end content container -->

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="BackToStart" -->
<!-- This can be deleted if it isn't needed -->
<style type="text/css">
#w2b-StoTop {-moz-border-radius: 5px;-webkit-border-radius: 5px;border-radius: 5px; width:100px;background-color: #EEEEEE;background-color: rgba(238, 238, 238, 0.6);filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorStr='#99EEEEEE',EndColorStr='#99EEEEEE');text-align:center;padding:5px;position:fixed;bottom:10px;right:10px;cursor:pointer;color:#444;text-decoration:none;border:1px solid #C9C9C9;}
</style>
<script type='text/javascript'>
    $(function() {
        $.fn.scrollToTop = function() {
            $(this).hide().removeAttr("href");
            if ($(window).scrollTop() != "0") {
                $(this).fadeIn("slow")
            }
            var scrollDiv = $(this);
            $(window).scroll(function() {
                if ($(window).scrollTop() == "0") {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeOut("slow")
                } else {
                    $(scrollDiv).fadeIn("slow")
                }
            });
            $(this).click(function() {
                $("html, body").animate({
                    scrollTop: 0
                }, "slow")
            })
        }
    });
    $(function() {
        $("#w2b-StoTop").scrollToTop();
    });
</script>
<a href='#' id='w2b-StoTop' style='display:none;'>Scroll to start<br />of page.</a><!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
